headline: Interesting Job, Toxic Environment
pros:
I note that the company has many departments, which all may differ from one another. The view below is solely based on my experience in my own department.

- You get exposure to the whole market you work in
- You work on interesting deals, many of which high profile
- You learn a great deal
- You meet and speak to many people in your industry
cons:
I note that the company has many departments, which all may differ from one another. The view below is solely based on my experience in my own department.

- You don't know who to turn to when you need to, not clear who your line manager is
- Senior team members can't give feedback on performance outside of designated times because they need to ask others, i.e. they have no opinion of you
- Everyone above you apparently is your boss, imagine what happens when you get told to do one thing by one and the opposite by another
- Work/Life balance is terrible, you have no life basically
- Face-time culture still exists, you can't leave before your boss(es) has(ve) left for the day even though you've done your job
- My team didn't have a leader, there was no structure and assignment of tasks were given to the team to split among themselves

At Lazard, I enjoyed extreme exposure, even as a first year analyst, to the MDs and Directors, working directly with them on numerous workstreams. As a result, I learnt skills and made contacts that I will be essential for the rest of my career. Also, my first year bonus was excellent compared to the industry average.
cons: Whilst it had been a problem before, in my final few months I saw senior management invest a lot of effort into modernising the workplace, promoting a positive and flexible work environment. headline: Risk Adversity Will be the Death of You
pros:
The tangibles: competitive pay in the industry, good health benefits, 401(k) match, physically nice office space since the renovations, generous tuition reimbursement, PTO allocations have improved, but are still under market. 

The intangibles: Having the opportunity to work with a lot of smart, motivated, people who were consumate professionals. Opportunities to take on more work and gain visibility to senior management. Expanded my knowledge base in the field 100-fold in the time I worked there.
cons:
Work-life balance is non-existent. It took me a while after I left to realize this was not normal: I worked nights, weekends, on vacations... It is a work-horse culture. I often found my directors/MDs would make it very difficult to take time off. I felt guilty about asking for time off! I think this is an industry-wide problem, even if it is particularly pronounced at Lazard. 

What really drove me crazy is a refusal to try to stand out - the position they took on everything was very firmly middle-of-the-pack. Lazard was/is/will likely be for a long time a solid enough brand and business where they can afford to take risks and do something different from what Evercore and Oppenheimer and Rothschild.

In It "User Satisfaction" was the main objective, but all priority was put on quick response to calls and emails, and not on prevention of system issues, like say redundancy in critical systems.  Even after Hurricane Sandy which crippled most of the company's IT infrastructure, there are   Nepotism ran rampant, so if you were somebodies friend, you could get away with murder.
